awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Structure and Function of Whole-tree 3D Xylem Networks in Response to Past, Present, and Future Drought
awd_abstract_narration:
Forest productivity is linked to the growth and maintenance of plant vascular systems that transport water from the soil to the leaves. These vascular systems are made up of a network of thousands of interconnected conduits smaller than the diameter of a human hair, collectively known as xylem. As plants are exposed to drought, this transport system can become dysfunctional, leading to reduced growth, and ultimately plant death. Current knowledge of the overall connectivity of the xylem network is limited, and this prevents a complete understanding of how water and nutrients are distributed through plants, and also limits the ability to predict how different species will adapt to limited water availability. The overarching goal of this project is to characterize the relationship between the three-dimensional (3D) structure of the xylem network and its function during drought in northeastern hardwood trees. The research will determine which tree species are most resilient under changing environmental conditions, establish tipping points beyond which species cannot recover from water deficits, and develop a model to predict widespread tree mortality under droughts of varying length and intensity. These data will inform conservation and timber production management by predicting shifts in tree mortality given environmental change scenarios. An online database will be created where 3D xylem models can be downloaded and then 3D-printed for use in biology and plant science classes, providing a unique, hands-on approach to learning plant functional anatomy. The project involves close collaboration between a major research university and a primarily undergraduate institution, thereby increasing undergraduate exposure to a research environment and education in STEM fields. 

Xylem network connectivity is one of the least understood areas of plant anatomy, primarily due to a lack of suitable visualization tools to study the complex, three-dimensional (3D) organization of the microscopic tissues that make up xylem. Plasticity in 3D xylem network anatomy is understood even less, yet it could have significant impacts on the movement of water, nutrients, pathogens, or drought and freeze-thaw induced embolisms. Furthermore, xylem network organization should influence commonly measured xylem vulnerability curves, but a mechanistic model that describes how these curves arise does not exist. Here, the aim is to use physiological and anatomical measurements of existing adult and juvenile trees, as well as juvenile trees in a common garden drought experiment, to explicitly test a range of hypotheses regarding the influence of xylem network connectivity in four dominant northeastern hardwood tree species. Using X-ray micro-tomography, wood samples from roots, trunks, and stems will be analyzed in 3D to explore the responses of trees to environmental changes over the past 15 years within close proximity to the Long Term Ecological Research site tower at Harvard Forest. A mechanistic model will then be developed to predict xylem vulnerability and physiological tipping points for each species at two life history stages to help understand how community dynamics will shift given changed environmental conditions. This project will support the career development of a postdoctoral associate, a beginning investigator, and provide opportunities for undergraduate research, including positions in the Harvard Forest Research Experiences for Undergraduates program.

por.por_cntn:
Forest productivity is linked to the growth and maintenance of plant vascular systems that transport water from the soil to the leaves. Water is transported to the top of the canopy through a network of thousands of interconnected conduits smaller than the diameter of a human hair, collectively known as xylem. As plants are exposed to drought conditions this transport system can become dysfunctional, leading to reduced forest productivity, and ultimately plant death. Current knowledge of the overall connectivity of the xylem network is surprisingly limited, and this knowledge gap prevents us from understanding how water and nutrients are distributed through plants, but also limits the ability to predict how different species will adapt to drought when the plant water transport breaks down. The goals achieved in this project include (1) demonstration of the effectiveness of using high-resolution X-ray micro-computed tomography (microCT) to study xylem structure and function, (2) characterization of the relationship between the three-dimensional (3D) structure of the xylem network and its function during drought in northeastern hardwood trees, and (3) elucidating the importance of inter-annual xylem connections in whole-tree water transport. We identified four dominant tree species in New England, and then determined their sensitivity to drought at the anatomical level. These data will inform conservation and timber production management by predicting shifts in tree mortality given current climate change scenarios. An online database was created where 3D xylem models can be downloaded and then 3D-printed for use in biology and plant science classes, providing a unique, hands-on approach to learning plant anatomy that highlights spatial organization in plants. There was a strong commitment to mentorship of both postdoctoral and undergraduate researchers for the entire duration of this NSF-supported research.

 

The efficiency of plant water transport depends greatly on the size and length of vascular conduits and the frequency and distribution of conduit endings (i.e. vessel end walls). Despite the importance of vessel end walls in woody plants, there lacks detailed anatomical descriptions and measurements of these structures. For the first time, with the use of microCT technology (Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory Advanced Light Source, Berkeley, CA, USA), we documented and measured vessel endings in red maple roots. Our analyses published in the American Journal of Botany (Wason et al., 2017) provided key information regarding the three-dimensional arrangement of vessel endings within xylem networks, improving our understating of xylem microstructure and function.

 

Climate models predict an increase in both the intensity and return frequency of drought, which may expose many tree species to stress levels beyond physiological thresholds that determine survival. As trees desiccate, embolism formation in the xylem becomes more likely and can lead to hydraulic dysfunction. The vulnerability segmentation hypothesis predicts that low-investment tissues (i.e. leaves, fine roots) should be more vulnerable to embolism spread, and may act as hydraulic fuses that prevent embolism spread into high-investment tissues (i.e. trunks, stems). We studied if drought tolerance and hydraulic safety margins of different plant tissues in four northern hardwood tree species support the segmentation hypothesis. We show that red maple (compared to white ash, American beech, and red oak) had the highest resistance to air seeding, with evidence that trunk vessels were more resistant than petiole and root vessels. In all four species, leaf tissue operated near or beyond their safety margins while perennial tissues were more conservative. Segmentation may not be as common as once thought. Lastly, even during the third driest summer in the past 100 years at the study site, all four tree species operated within their safety margins at our study site, (white ash, American beech, and red oak; Wason et al. 2018). White ash showed the greatest risk of hydraulic failure, and when coupled with recent declines due to damage from the emerald ash borer, is the most vulnerable of the study species in the long term. 

 

Finally, in trees most water transport is restricted to the current-year growth ring, but functional xylem and water storage persists in older rings. Connections across growth-ring boundaries could therefore increase hydraulic redundancy and access to water stored in older rings. However, drought and freeze-thaw events can lead to air bubbles in the xylem that block water transport, so cross-ring connections could expose current-year xylem to residual air-embolisms in old growth-rings. We used xylem dye-staining and microCT to determine the presence or absence of cross-ring connections in four temperate woody trees to understand the implications of connections between current-year and older growth-rings. Our findings show that red maple and white ash have cross-ring connections, but only red maple used multiple rings for axial sap flow. The use of multiple years of xylem may be correlated with vulnerability segmentation in red maple as documented in our research (Wason et al. 2019).
